content:
The study of the typical development of echinoderms will in-
clude observations on the following forms: A) the starfish
(Asterlas), B) the sand dollar (Rchinarachnius), and C) the sea
urchin (Arbacia). The following points will be considered:
l. Morphology of the gametes.
2. Maturation of the ovum.
5. Fertilization
4. Cleavage of the zygote.
5. Gastrulation.
6. Organogeny and metamorphosis.
This will be followed by several experimental studies.. A par~
tial list of experiments suggested will be found below.
ln order that material of different stages be available at
all times, the instructor in charge will place stock cultures of'
different ages on the tables. Please he careful to avoid con-
taminating tmsse. This may be avoided by using only the pipette
found in each dish for securing material from that culture.
lt is essential that material be conserved. This is especially
true in the case of the starfish. Ripe individuals have gonads in
each of the rays. One of the arms may, therefore, be removed and
the gametes which issue from the gonad may be made to serve a large
number of students. When one arm is removed from an animal, that
animal should be placed in a special container in order that,
should it be a male; the sperm shall not infect females opened in
the same way. The same care in conservation should be used with
Echinarachnius and Arbacia as well.
Echinoderms are diocious, i.e. the sexes are separate. It is
impossible, however, to distinguish the male from the female by
superficial examination. It is necessary to open animals until
ripe individuals of each sex are found. This should be done in the
following ways. A) starfish: Wash the animal and all instruments
and hands in fresh tap~water to Kill any adhering spermatozoa. Now
rinse well in running sea-water from the tap. One of the
arms should now be removed. With forceps remove the gonad which
lies free in the cavity of the ray and place in a dish.without
sea~water. The gonads of the males are white; those of the female
are orange-yellow. The gametes will flow from the isolated gonad.
Female gonads should be placed immediately in a finger bowl con~
taining sea~water. The male gonads should be left in a watch 
in order that the sperm may be obtained 'dry'. When eggs cease to
flow from the female gonad, the fleshy part should be removed and
the ova washed several times in the following way. Add a considerable
amount of sea-water to the eggs and allow thenato settle. Now pour
off the water and add a fresh supply. This does not remove very
small fragments of the ovary but it does serve to eliminate a great
deal of the body fluid mrids may chance to be present. E(Echinarach-
nius: Wash the animals as described above. Cut across the animal
with a heavy pair of scissors. The gonads will be exposed. Place
the males inya clean dry dish in order that 'dry' sperm will be
available. Wash the eggs extruded from.the ovaries (which are
purple in color) as described above for the starfish. sea~urchin:
After washing the animals, puncture the soft tissue at the peristome
with a sharp pair of scissors and out around the equator exposing the
